body: To stay consistent with the other languages the package should probably be renamed to `grpcio_tools`.
CC @jtattermusch
Aaand this should somehow be integrated into the template system and/or have a sanity check to ensure  additive protobuf dependency changes don't break the package.
Turns out that the GCC weirdness was fixed somewhere between 4.8.4 and 6.1.

@jtattermusch I've checked this now on Mac OS X El Capitan (Python 2.7 amd64), Windows x64 (Python 2.7 amd64 and i686), and Linux x64 (Python 2.7 amd64).

Building on Windows requires a Mingw32 `clang` or `gcc` (5.3+)  environment w/ any of the MSVC compiled Python 2.7s. Invocation looks something like this on a 32 bit Python build (in a mingw32 32-bit environment):

```
$ /c/Python27/python.exe setup.py build_ext -c mingw32
$ /c/Python27/python.exe setup.py bdist_wheel
```

and on a 64 bit build (in a mingw32 64-bit environment):

```
$ /c/Python27/python.exe setup.py build_ext -c mingw32 -D MS_WIN64
$ /c/Python27/python.exe setup.py bdist_wheel
```

Are we blocking on sanity test and template-system integration?

I guess I should at least add a doc with instructions first?

<sup>n.b. I say 'requires', but really anything that can compile C++11 code on Windows and is supported by distutils (so, anything that isn't `vcpython27` due to the first condition) should work</sup>
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle Do we want this named `grpcio-protoc` or `grpcio_protoc`?
I thought we wanted to name this grpcio-tools or grpcio_tools  to be consistent with other languages?

Questions:
Once the python packages are installed, how do I use this  (can you provide the wheels for testing)?
Do you intend to build this manually or is there integration into our jenkins artifact builder (if not, do we have a plan how to integrate)?
What is the plan for integrating with the sanity test?
I'm not sure about the names `grpc_python_protoc_compiler.py`  and `grpc_python_protoc_plugin.py`
Why aren't you just distributing the existing `protoc` and `grpc_python_plugin` plugins, and running them with `subprocess`? That's what I did for Node and Ruby, and it was pretty simple.

Am I right saying that with this approach the actual protoc  and grpc_python_plugin binaries actually don't exist? I think that can be pretty confusing for users. I think it's fine to provide some wrapper around them (like what you're doing), but they really should be usable on their own.

The point was to keep out of the way of any actual protoc or plugin installation the user performs. The concept of 'usable on their own' doesn't make much sense to me here; the exact same code is being invoked in either case. The next step is directly integrating the plugin with the protoc wrapper so that the user need not do the `--plugin=protoc-gen-python-grpc=grpc_python_protoc_plugin.py` flag magic I mentioned above (and that can only be done by wrapping).
Ideally the scripts `grpc_python_protoc_*.py` will be removed, but I had to expose them for now s.t. the plugin could be invoked as the wrapping, while functional, isn't finished.
@jtattermusch Now integrated with sanity tests. Will integrate with jenkins artifact builder.
@jtattermusch Linux builders integrated (you may now test the wheels generated in that way); Windows will be a bit more involved.
Protoc and plugin have been tightly integrated, obviating the extra long flag. Invocation is now `python -m grpc.protoc.compiler --python_out=... --grpc_python_out=... [files and stuff]`.

@soltanmm: lacking any technical justification one way or the other, hyphen is how the spirit is moving me at the moment. I took a quick look at PyPI and saw hyphens, underscores, dots, and even letter case being used as word separators in package names. Let's avoid using letter case, but I don't have any strong feelings about the rest.
This PR will have conflicts with #6318.
Can I please have a link to  a successful artifact build?

I tried to run the artifact builder and most of the artifact builders on linux seem to be broken
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/view/Artifacts/job/gRPC_build_artifacts/686/
@jtattermusch Err, hm. Missing clang in the docker images...
@soltanmm  Haven't  you said you tried this and it was working?

@jtattermusch I said the build works on individual test machines; I'd not yet tried over Jenkins (though I'll admit I did wrongly assume that all the tools needed were available on Jenkins for it to Just Work).

[This](https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/view/Artifacts/job/gRPC_build_artifacts/704/) should be a successful build. I _think_ our workstations all use `py27mu` builds, but if `pip install`ing that doesn't work try the other tag (`py27mu` is what works for me).

This PR now also fixes #6036 (for my yak is the most beautiful of them all).

cc @nicolasnoble w.r.t. the excess of hard-coded precompiler definition flags added to the `artifact_targets.py` script.

I tried the wheels from the successful linux build:

```
pip install grpcio_tools-0.14.0.dev0-cp27-cp27mu-manylinux1_x86_64.whl 
grpcio_tools-0.14.0.dev0-cp27-cp27mu-manylinux1_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.
```

```
pip install grpcio_tools-0.14.0.dev0-cp27-cp27m-manylinux1_x86_64.whl 
grpcio_tools-0.14.0.dev0-cp27-cp27m-manylinux1_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.
```

My pip version:

```
pip --version
pip 8.1.1 from /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip-8.1.1-py2.7.egg (python 2.7)
```
Also (less importantly) the grpcio_tools wheel is 18MB in size, so perhaps the binary is not stripped properly.

Another problem is that the all the linux distribution tests for the build you posted are failing:
https://grpc-testing.appspot.com/view/Artifacts/job/gRPC_distribtest/636/

@jtattermusch I'm not sure how you tested the wheels, but there's a funny quirk of our work machines we have wherein it's possible for us to have two pip installations and have them interfere with one another. Could you please check if `sudo which pip` and `which pip` are the same?
